body: Please note I have https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/12305 in review.
Yeah, that's independant. This PR is to actually hook event processing in so that cares is pumping bytes using gRPC's notifications.

Thanks for adding the windows event driver! It looks great! I think we can enable this test https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/tools/run_tests/run_tests_matrix.py#L251 in this PR.
Good point, thanks, I'll mutate that script.

---

Reviewed 18 of 20 files at r1, 2 of 2 files at r2, 1 of 1 files at r3.
Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 5 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed.

---

*[src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_ev_driver_windows.c, line 37 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/12416#-Ktr77CtE6JJzKtdnIH4:-Ktr77CtE6JJzKtdnIH5:b-5dicaw) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/f060abc3aed658168e344cc641cad84afaf28309/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_ev_driver_windows.c#L37)):*
> ```C
> #include "src/core/lib/support/string.h"
> 
> typedef struct fd_node {
> ```

General comment on this file: Although there is certainly some Windows-specific code here, there is also a lot of overlap with the existing posix driver.  Would it make sense to refactor somehow to avoid so much duplication?

Feel free to push back on this; I'm honestly not sure whether or not this makes sense.  I guess I'm just worried about the possibility of fixing a bug in one of the two files and then forgetting to update the other one.

---

*[src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_ev_driver_windows.c, line 243 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/12416#-Ktr6CGNuk_6BcDDuztP:-Ktr6CGNuk_6BcDDuztQ:b-6ej45s) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/f060abc3aed658168e344cc641cad84afaf28309/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_ev_driver_windows.c#L243)):*
> ```C
>           char *fd_name;
>           gpr_asprintf(&fd_name, "ares_ev_driver-%" PRIuPTR, i);
>           fdn = gpr_malloc(sizeof(fd_node));
> ```

Need a cast here due to impending C++ build.

---

*[src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_ev_driver_windows.c, line 244 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/12416#-Ktr6Mcd1rWaHftkfFTn:-Ktr6Mcd1rWaHftkfFTo:b-fk9e0s) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/f060abc3aed658168e344cc641cad84afaf28309/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_ev_driver_windows.c#L244)):*
> ```C
>           gpr_asprintf(&fd_name, "ares_ev_driver-%" PRIuPTR, i);
>           fdn = gpr_malloc(sizeof(fd_node));
>           gpr_log(GPR_DEBUG, "new socket: 0x%" PRIxPTR, (uintptr_t)socks[i]);
> ```

Does `%p` not work on Windows?

---

*[src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_ev_driver_windows.c, line 259 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/12416#-Ktr6deE02FCUaG85e-s:-Ktr6deE02FCUaG85e-t:b-9zteo3) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/f060abc3aed658168e344cc641cad84afaf28309/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_ev_driver_windows.c#L259)):*
> ```C
>         new_list = fdn;
>         gpr_mu_lock(&fdn->mu);
>         // There's not a lot of good ways to poll sockets using the IOCP loop.
> ```

Maybe preface this comment with `TODO(nnoble):`, so that people know who the "I" in the comment refers to? :)

---

*[src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.c, line 239 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/12416#-Ktr3huwcvq89Jg6YND8:-Ktr3huwcvq89Jg6YND9:b-k8genu) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/451b92a754900a800a7728a3d63462058026ac2c/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.c#L239)):*
> ```C
>       for (struct ares_srv_reply *srv_it = reply; srv_it != NULL;
>            srv_it = srv_it->next) {
>         if (grpc_ipv6_loopback_available()) {
> ```

Hmm... The extra lookups for the IPv6 records do add latency, so it probably does make sense to avoid them if we know that we don't have an IPv6 loopback address.  Is there a reasonable way to do that, maybe by implementing a dummy version of `grpc_ipv6_loopback_available()` on Windows?

---


*Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/12416#-:-Ktr7_22O2ztC6Wovcwl:bxgavm9)*
<!-- Sent from Reviewable.io -->
Might need to incorporate similar changes to the ones from #12631.

Any news or timeline on this one? This would greatly help to make gRPC useful in non-containerized windows environments. Right now, we are pretty limited to use workarounds since it's not feasable for us to change the OS DNS server at a customer site.

#13639 is our current workaround for that, but I would prefer to just replace the GRPCLB dummy with a DNS implementation which can be used with c-ares. Would be the much cleaner approach. Since there is still no custom name resolver support in C# (#11879) there is no nicer option than adding something to c-core (#13639) and use it in C#, or to use what's already there (soon) with c-ares.

I am also keen for an update. I asked a couple of times on Gitter but I think it got lost in the noise. I have been setting expectations that it would be early Q1 of this year based on the last estimate. Its a blocker to going live for us.
Sorry for the delay, I'll look at landing this one shortly.
Investigating using c-ares dns functionality on windows environment. Would be good if you could give at least rough idea of timelines here, please.
Hi guys. Any update on 'shortly'? Are we talking 1-3 months or 3-6? Sorry, I know I am being a bit 'chasey'
Any news? I had hoped for it to be included in 1.11.0, but seems like we just missed that release :(
Hey. Seeing a bit of activity here which is encouraging. Is this still the correct PR to follow?
Hi. Bumping this thread. I am still super keen to know when this will land.
V1.15 was released yesterday and according to the release notes this should be part of it :) at least part of the compilation but not enabled on windows

@Falco20019 you are referring to https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/16163?

@dunkymole https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/15914 and https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/16420 make the c-ares resolver useable on Windows. Those PR's are merged but haven't made it into a release (they should be available in the [nightlies](https://packages.grpc.io/) though).
Exciting news @apolcyn. Thanks for the update!! :-)

@apolcyn Are there any news on this topic or issues that I should follow besides this one? It's becoming more and more a blocker for us since we have to rely on a separate DNS since we are not allowed to manage the DNS servers in the customers IT and also not allowed to modify the DNS server to use on the machines.

@Falco20019 https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/15914 made c-ares usable on Windows back in August, and a follow-up localhost resolution fixed was merged not long after in #16420 (I looked through the release notes from back then and these PR's do seem to be missing from the release notes; sorry if that's confusing). So, you should be able to use c-ares on Windows starting from the 1.16.0 release, by running your binary under environment variable setting `GRPC_DNS_RESOLVER=ares`.... is this not currently working for you?
